Children\u2019s ICU begins functioning a.description: COIMBATORE: An advanced intensive care unit for children, which was inaugurated last month, began functioning at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital here on Monday. The children’s ICU, which will provide a more sanitized ambience for critical care and a lesser risk of infections, has been set up in the first floor of the old CT scan building. It is equipped with 16 beds, each of which can be remotely operated and offer five different positions. “This will make children more comfortable while they are being made to undergo various procedures, like tube feeding, inserting a ventilator among others. Each bed has also been equipped with oxygen, suction facilities and equipment to monitor vitals,” GH dean Dr B Ashokan said. Earlier the children’s ICU was functioning in a portion of the pediatric surgical unit. Children above the age of one usually require intensive care if they suffer from a severe infection that has progressed to septicemia, severe asthmatic attacks or generally any infection that affects their respiratory tract. “Since children’s trachea and bronchi are very tiny, severe infections like encephalitis or the flu immediately leads to breathing and oxygen intake issues, which sometimes need oxygen or ventilator,” the dean said. The hospital serves children from at least four nearby districts. They come with different types of severe infections, which progresses to septicemia before they are referred to us, the dean said. Private hospitals charge Rs 20,000 a day for the same facilities, while in GH its free, he said. The space for the ward was handed over to Rotary Club of Satellite, who roped in two private firms—Aquasub and Jewel one— and raised Rs 1.2 crore. They built the ward and handed it over back to GH. NGO helps dropouts to return to school.description: COIMBATORE: Thanks to the efforts of Vizhuthugal Organization, an NGO, over 200 school dropouts from the rural parts of the western districts are continuing education. “With the help of volunteers and women self-help groups, we identified over 200 school dropouts in the villages of Annur block in Coimbatore, Avinashi block in Tirupur and Nambiyur block in Erode and took measures to send them back to schools. The students were constantly monitored to ensure that they do not drop out again,” said M Thangavel, director of the organization. Compared to girls in rural areas, it is the boys, who are often forced to quit schools. More than 65% of the dropouts from the blocks were boys, Thangavel said. “To understand the reasons behind it, we conducted a study in the blocks. We chose the blocks as several child marriages were reported from there. Child labour was also rampant at these three places.” “We had selected 20 villages in Nambiyur block and started children resource centres (CRC) in each village to assist the children two years ago. Apart from guiding them through their academic syllabus, other assistance like counselling and life skill guidance were given to them. In the last two years, no child marriage, no child labour and no school dropouts were reported from those villages,” Thangavel said. The NGO has now identified 60 villages to launch the CRCs. “The main reason for dropout among boys is the poor financial situation in their families. After a certain age, they would be encouraged to work rather than study. Initially, it took us a lot of time to convince the parents, but eventually they accepted and started sending their children to schools. Now, many of the them are in colleges,” said S Vidhya, a facilitator from Ekalikovilmedu village in Nambiyur block. Many parents assume that the schools would not admit their wards if they are absent for three months and do not make any attempt to admit them again, Vidhya said. “Everything else would fall in place if enough awareness is created.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Farmers want permission to graze cattle.description: COIMBATORE: A group of cattle farmers from villages in and around Thondamuthur approached the Coimbatore district collector for permission to graze their cows in forestland again. They said the population of native cattle breeds, specifically the Malai Kongu Maadu, had dropped drastically after farmers were banned from grazing their cattle in reserve forest zones. They also demanded that the price at which Aavin buys A2 milk from farmers be raised to encourage more farmers to breed and maintain native cow breeds. Farmers, led by the Kongu Patteeshwaran Ghoshala, have requested the collector to make the forest department again issue “patti passes” to cattle farmers. “This is a pass that the forest department was issuing to allow us to graze our cattle in forest areas and lands. Around 2000-01, there were nearly 1.5 lakh to two lakh Malai Kongu cows in villages in and around Thondamuthur including Madhampatti, Karadimadai and Viraliyur,” said T Shanmugam a member of the Ghoshala. “However, in 2002, when the forest department withdrew our patti passes and banned our and our cattle’s entry into forest areas, many farmers panicked and sold thousands of their native cows to slaughterhouses. We hardly have a few thousand cows of the native breed left,” he said. The farmers said the government should incentivise rearing of native breeds of cattle. “While one way is to allow us to graze in forest areas, the other one is to make Aavin buy A2 milk from farmers for at least Rs 50 to Rs 60 per litre. They currently buy it for Rs 20 per litre, which is the cost for A1 milk. They have only one category called milk,” said Shanmugam. “They should also ban construction on hill area conservation lands and foothills of mountains, because it eventually takes away greenery and open lands which can be used for grazing,” he added. The cattle farmers said that the ban on cattle has affected their environment in multiple ways. “Whenever our cattle used to graze in the forest fringes, wild animals never came out of the forest. We have never seen wild elephants, bears and leopards. Now they have begun coming to our villages,” the petition said. “The cow’s urine and dung were so beneficial to the soil that the forests were thicker and they used to eat grass so well, that fresh grass kept growing. Now we have less greenery and temperature is higher. We have also had to start using chemical pesticides, because we don’t have enough cow urine to make biopesticides,” it said. DMK members stage protest in Coimbatore.description: COIMBATORE: Police on Wednesday detained 512 DMK members, including Singanallur legislator N Karthik, for protesting in front of the Coimbatore City Municipal Corporation (CCMS) office. Of them, 118 were women. They were demanding regular distribution of drinking water. Karthik announced the protest earlier this week. On Wednesday morning, police denied permission for it. However, the members staged a protest despite that. They were detained and were lodged in a marriage hall. Karthik said they had protested demanding water supply once in three to four days. “Also, we seek resignation of minister for municipal administration S P Velumani as he has not taken proactive measures to handle the water situation,” he said. They also protested the municipal body giving the water supply rights to a private firm. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. Polluting industrial unit downs shutter.description: COIMBATORE: Days after the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) sought explanation from a private company in Malumichampatti, which was found discharging untreated industrial effluents, the firm was found closed. “Based on a complaint from a farmers’ association, we inspected the electroplating company and found it discharging effluents into a chock pit and polluting soil and water. It had not obtained license from TNPCB,” an official said. Equipment were removed from the company premises and the company was found closed. “They have closed the company on their own. But they still have to give a reply and based on it, final decision will be taken,” the official said. TOI had carried a report explaining how the company, which is situated amid farmlands, had been polluting underground water and soil. “The company, surrounded by farmlands for over 50 acres, began functioning just a couple of months ago. Initially, there weren’t any issues. Locals noticed the company releasing untreated industrial effluents that had traces of chromium. After we raised questions, they dug a chock pit started to discharge the effluents into the pit,” said V Vishnusankar, a farmer. Farmers in the area had blamed the firm after crops including banana plants started to wither. “A borewellthe only source of water to the entire villageis situation just a few hundred metres from the company,” Vishnusankar said. The TNPCB official said that they were yet to receive a reply from the company and based on the reply, action would be taken. “Permission will not be given to run a company amid agricultural land,” he added. TNEB cuts power supply to Jeeva Ngr resi.description: Coimbatore: Heeding to a request from the city corporation, the Tamil Nadu Electricity Board (TNEB) suspended power connection to all the houses at Jeeva Nagar in Kavundampalayam in the city on Tuesday. The corporation took the stern action after issuing several eviction notices and holding talks with the residents many a times to vacate their houses in the past two years. Town planning officer (TPO) S Ravichandran said, “There are 252 houses at Jeeva Nagar. We issued eviction notice to all the houses shortly after the Madras high court gave a direction in 2017. Over a period, 132 families moved to the houses provided by the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board at Keeranatham.” As the rest of the residents were refusing to vacate their houses and move to alternative accommodation, the corporation suspended the electricity connection, he said. The corporation had earlier demolished the houses of 90 families who had moved to Keeranatham. The high court gave the direction to remove the encroachments based on a writ petition filed by members of KK Pudur Residents Welfare Association. The petitioners contented that the 50-feet link road, which is a part of designated cart road, for over a kilometre stretch is encroached and none of the emergency service vehicles, including ambulance and fire service vehicles, could enter the street because of the encroachment. The legal battle had commenced as early as 2000. “If the encroachments are removed and the road is developed, it would significantly reduce the traffic congestion in both NSR Road and Kavundampalayam Road in the city as it connects Thadagam Road and Mettupalayam Road,” secretary of the association KKM Selvaraj, who had filed a writ petition demanding the removal of encroachments, said. But residents refused to move out of their houses for different reasons. “The residents are not encroachers at all. They have been paying a sum between Rs 80,000 and Rs one lakh in installments to the slum clearance board to own the land. In 1990s, the TNSCB has signed a lease cum agreement with the residents. As per the agreement, residents would be provided patta if they pay a sum between Rs 2,000 and Rs 8,000 per square feet of their house,” district president of the Tamil Nadu Odukapattor Valvurimai Iyyakam A Ashraf Ali, who have been working with the residents, said. Explaining that most of the residents are daily wage labourers, he said the residents are ready to move if alternative accommodation was arranged somewhere in the same locality as their livelihood would be affected upon moving to a different location. Acknowledging that such an agreement was signed, an official from TNSCB said it was to compensate the amount that they had paid, they were provided alternative accommodation at free of cost and they have no other option but to obey court’s order. Layout promoter trying to sell park site.description: COIMBATORE: A year has lapsed since the city corporation claimed ownership of the open space reservation (OSR) site of Ram Residency near Uppilipalayam in the city, but the layout promoter is now making arrangements to sell the land. Activists have petitioned the city corporation officials, urging them to take immediate steps to retrieve the land. The layout was formed in 1988 with 21 plots. About 10% of the total layout area - i.e., 28.37 cents - was reserved to create a park site, as per the directorate of town and country planning (DTCP) approval. As per the Town and Country Planning Act and high court directions, the land reserved as OSR could not be used for any other purpose and none other than the local body could claim ownership of it. But the norms are being violated here, said activist S P Thiyagarajan, who escalated the issue. “The corporation had regularized the OSR land in 2009 and collected vacant land tax for the property. It, however, issued building approval licence in 2011. The land was then documented in the name of the layout promoter’s brother and later purchased in 2013. But no construction activities were carried out in the plot till date,” he said. The issue came to light only when the promoter fenced the plot in 2018. After the residents lodged a complaint, the city corporation installed a board claiming its ownership, the activist said. “It is the only open space we have in our layout. If it is turned into a park, it will be useful for us for recreational activities as almost every household has a child,” said B Harisudan, secretary of Ram residency welfare association. Pointing out that the promoter was working to sell the plot, he said the city corporation should take immediate action to retrieve the site and develop it into a park. When contacted, town planning official S Ravichandran assured to look into the issue and take immediate action. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Ola drivers stage protest in Coimbatore.description: COIMBATORE: Around 200 drivers who work for private cab aggregator Ola staged a demonstration in front of its office at R S Puram here to protest a cut in salaries. The drivers said the company had been paying them almost Rs 23,000 per month. Now they are paid Rs 13,000 per month. The protesters entered the Ola office premises and continued their protest. As a result of the protest, many people who tried booking Ola cabs in the suburbs ended up facing delays and cancellations, forcing them to look for other options. The drivers said they had been receiving a reduced salary for the past two months and so they could not run their families with it. “We are employees who take vehicles on lease from Ola and pay the lease amount periodically. We also used to earn a bonus for driving 12 hours a day. With the bonus itself amounting to Rs 300 to Rs 400 a day, we could pay the lease amount of Rs 800 per day and still take home around Rs 900 per day or Rs 23,000 a month,” said a protester named Balaji. “However, for the past two months, we have been getting a bonus of Rs 50 to Rs 100 a day, so after paying the lease amount, we hardly get Rs 500 a day which is insufficient to run our families,” he said. Ola officials in Coimbatore were not available for comment despite multiple attempts by TOI. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. The Times of India does not support or promote piracy in any manner.Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani. Proper road sought to connect Runnymede.description: UDHAGAMANDALAM: The Heritage Steam Chariot Trust (HSCT) has sought the intervention of the Nilgirst district administration to lay tar road connecting Runnymede station and the Katteri government garden. Tourists who take the roundtrip joyride on the NMR train between Coonoor and Runneymede visit the Katteri government garden for an hour as part of the journey. At present, only a mud road connects the Runnymede garden with the garden. Founder trustee of HSCT K Natarajan said, “We have requested the district administration to pitch in to develop a proper road connecting the garden and the Runnymede station.” He said, “There exists a mud road with a width of more than 12 feet running to 500m to reach the Runnymede station. That should be developed as a proper road to facilitate the NMR tourists, who take the joyride to Runnymede.” Based on the request by HSCT, Nilgiris collector J Innocent Divya held an inspection along with officials of horticulture and forest departments at the spot on Wednesday. The collector also suggested for a small trekking experience for the tourists besides making availability of tribal food in the garden. The joyride trip stops at Runnymede station for an hour for the tourists to enjoy the scenic beauty and visit the Kattery government garden. With different levels of terrains, the garden extends to an area of around 6 acres, with several backdrops including Western Ghat range. Natarajan said, “The collector assured that a proper road would be developed connecting the garden and the railway station soon.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Private industrial estate to come up nea.description: Coimbatore: A private industrial estate that would house foundries, engineering units and units that make wet grinders, UPVC doors and windows is all set to come up on a 55-acre plot at Devampalayam village in Sarkar Samakulam.The genesis of the estate, christened ‘Nethaji Industrial Estate’, was in 1997, said P Soundararajan, the secretary of the Nethaji Industrial Estate Society. “About 100 like-minded industrialists got together and decided to set up an industrial estate outside the city, so that we could shift our plants, which are inside the city limits. We decided this as it would be favourable in aspects such as pollution control,” he told TOI.The group purchased 55 acres at Devampalayam in 1997. “In 2007 we got the land converted for industrial use and in 2016, applied for the layout approval. We got the approval in December 2018,” said Soundararajan. The society had declared the investment at the first Global Investors Meet in 2015.The next step was to develop common infrastructure such as roads, stormwater drains and electric lights. The industrialists have estimated a budget of Rs 15crore for the work.As the state gives subsidy for setting up private industrial estates, the society has applied for it through the Tamil Nadu Small Industries Development Corporation Limited (SIDCO). “We are expecting the sanction within two months. After that, we would implement the project in six months,” Soundararajan said.Currently, the member industries have plants operating in the city at places such as Ganapathi and Avarampalayam. The members plan to move to the estate and expand their facilities there.“After we set up the estate, we expect an annual business of Rs 150crore,” he added.Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Old answer scripts on truck spill on roa.description: COIMBATORE: Old answer scripts from the Anna University Regional Campus at Navavoor on the Maruthamalai Main Road in Coimbatore, which were being carried on a truck to be weighed and pulped, spilled on the road at Vadavalli here on Monday morning. M Saravanakumar, dean of the campus, said the answer scripts were more than a year old and were being taken to the Tamil Nadu Newsprint and Papers Limited (TNPL) at Karur to be pulped. He said as per the government norms, nullified answer scripts - that are more than a year old - should be taken to TNPL for pulping. When the papers were being carried by the truck, they spilled on the road at Vadavalli in the city. A mini truck was brought to the spot, and a portion of the papers were transferred to it and then taken away. Sources said the papers were not loaded properly on the truck, which might have caused the mishap. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. In Video:Congress refused to forge alliance with AAP for LS polls: KejriwalDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Forest dept issues wild elephant alert.description: Coimbatore: The forest department has appealed to pilgrims and fitness freaks, who frequently climb the steps to Marudhamalai, not to do so at dawn and after 8pm as wild elephants are frequenting the place. “Many people from Vadavalli, Kalvirampalayam and Pommanapalayam go for the regular walks early in the morning to Marudhamalai. They climb up the steps and walk back down through the road. Many do so even after 8pm. There has been an increase in the movement of elephants from forest areas like Anaikatto, Mankarai and Thadagam that cross the Bharathiar University to Narasipuram, Nagarajapuram and even Velliangiri,” said an official. Swachh Bharat subsidy: Block co-ordinato.description: COIMBATORE: Acting on TOI reports, Palladam block development officer (BDO) S Balamurugan terminated block co-ordinator K Maheshwari from service for collecting bribe from the residents of Ichipatti village to facilitate subsidy for constructing toilets under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. The termination order was issued on Saturday. Panchayat secretary Suresh Kumar, who was working at the panchayat in 2016, was also suspended for failing to monitor and control such activities in his panchayat. A senior official from the district rural development agency (DRDA) said, “In 2016, Maheshwari was in charge of identifying the households without toilets and assisting the villagers to construct a toilet under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan scheme. Motivator Sathya was in charge of motivating the public to join the scheme. But they had collected Rs 1,500 - Rs 2,000 per house as bribe and promised them to get a government subsidy of Rs 12,000 for each toilet. Believing their words, the villagers constructed the toilets by taking loans. But the villagers never got the government subsidy. All these came out during an inquiry conducted by the BDO after TOI reported about the scam on June 11.” “It is also proved that the bribe amount - Rs 1.48 lakh - which Maheshwari distributed to 87 villagers on June 13 was her own money and not the incentive amount of Sathya as she claimed. Sathya was dismissed one and half years ago,” the official added. The block co-ordinator and motivator are temporary posts filled by BDO, who has powers to terminate them. In its report on June 11, TOI revealed that over 100 residents of Ichipatti village near Palladam in Tirupur were waiting for the subsidy for more than three years after constructing household toilets by taking loans. Though the original scheme envisages funding – subsidy of Rs 12,000 per toilet - at various stages of construction, the prospective beneficiaries had to beg and borrow to construct toilets as the officials had only promised to reimburse the expenditure once the facility is ready. Medicines supplied to govt health centre.description: TIRUPUR: Ion tablets, medicines used in oral rehydration threapy, and other drugs distributed in government health centres and hospitals were found dumped at Alangiyam near Dharapuram here on Monday. Health officials said the medicines, which were not expired, were mostly given to pregnant women. While they were yet to ascertain why the medicines were dumped, they found that the medicines were from the batches supplied to district health centres. The district administration has ordered inquiry into the issue. Locals, who noticed the medicines at a graveyard adjacent to a water pumping station near Amaravathi River, informed the authorities. District health department officials along with police reached the spot, collected the dumped medicines and sent them to the primary health centre at Ponnapuram. Jayanthi Somasundaram, deputy director of health services, Tirupur, said, “We have started inquiry into the issue. We are in contact with the Tamil Nadu Medical Services Corporation to find out the batches to which the medicines belonged. We are verifying medicine stocks in health sub centres and primary health centres.” When contacted, Dharapuram sub-collector Pavankumar G Giriyappanavar told TOI, “We have been informed about the dumping. We will take appropriate action against people who are responsible for it.” Since the dumped medicines posed threat to environment and loss to the exchequer, it has caused outrage among the people in the area. India Pakistan news.description: NEW DELHI/ISLAMABAD: India dismissed on Thursday as "fake news" the suggestion in Pak media that it was looking to resume talks with the hostile neighbour and asserted that there was no dilution of its position that Islamabad needed to take verifiable and irreversible action against terrorism for the dialogue to resume. Responding to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's congratulatory letter after he assumed office for the second time, PM Narendra Modi wrote back on June 12 expressing India's desire to have normal and cooperative relations with all its neighbours, including Pakistan, while stressing that "for this, it is important to build an environment of trust, free of terror, violence and hostility". Foreign minister S Jaishankar also wrote to his Pakistani counterpart S M Qureshi, again only in response to the latter's congratulatory letter, emphasising the need for an atmosphere "free from the shadow of terror and violence". The emphasis on the need for Pakistan to rein in terror as a pre-condition for re-engagement was in keeping with the stand which saw Modi refrain from engaging with Imran Khan at the just-concluded SCO summit in Kyrgyzstan. Yet, the Pakistani media chose to interpret the contents of the letters of Modi and Jaishankar as reflecting India's desire to re-engage. The foreign ministry in Delhi quickly scotched the suggestion. "There was complete distortion and an attempt to peddle fake news (in the way it was reported). The letters only reiterated India's old position that it wants normal and cooperative relations with all countries in South Asia and that it was important to create an environment free of terror and violence for it. There was no mention of any sort of dialogue with Pakistan," said MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar, adding that India will not be fooled by any cosmetic action against terror by Islamabad. Emphasising that both the letters were written in as per the "established diplomatic practice", Kumar said: "In their messages, they have highlighted that India seeks normal and cooperative relations with all neighbours, including Pakistan." In his letter, Modi had said that India remained committed to operationalising early an "all-year-round" Kartarpur corridor. Touching upon it, Kumar said India had already held three technical-level discussions with Pakistan and was currently awaiting clarification from Islamabad over a few issues it had raised. Puzzlingly, later in the evening, Pakistan's foreign ministry, which had kept quiet through the day, also sought to play down the speculation about the import of the letters. While responding to a question, the spokesperson said, "It was an established practice for the leadership to congratulate new office holders and for them to respond." "Pakistan's position on the way forward in relations with India was clear and well-known and did not require repetition," said the spokesperson, adding that the "vision of peace, progress and prosperity of South Asia could be advanced by peacefully resolving all outstanding disputes, including Jammu & Kashmir, and moving away from dynamic of confrontation to cooperation". Earlier in the day, sources in the Pakistan foreign office had said that Modi and Jaishankar had responded positively to recent letters from their Pakistani counterparts by conveying New Delhi's desire to engage with all countries, including Pakistan, for elimination of terrorism and prosperity of the region. "India has always prioritised peace and human development, and sought to maintain cordial relations with all regional powers," Modi and Jaishankar maintained, according to FO sources. Both leaders, according to FO sources, called for special attention on elimination of terrorism in the region and said the issue must be a core focus in all future talks. They have also appreciated sentiments from Pakistan in their letters, the FO sources added. Modi's letter was in response to a congratulatory letter from Khan in which he had underscored Pakistan's vision of working for "durable peace and stability in South Asia with peaceful resolution of all outstanding disputes, including J&K". Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Three arrested for swindling Rs 5 crore.description: COIMBATORE: The city crime branch police on Tuesday arrested three men, who were employed in a private firm, for allegedly swindling more than Rs 5 crore from the firm. Police identified the accused as S Chidambaram, 46, V Murali, 36 and V Selvakumar, 32. The trio were employed with ‘Beauty wares’, a firm which sells tiles and other materials for houses. It was run by S Sivakumar, 47, of Ganapathy. Chidambaram was employed as executive director, Murali waas incharge officer at the purchase department, and Selvakumar was an accountant at the firm, police said. “Sivakumar lodged a complaint with the city crime branch police that the three men had forged bills and involved in the misappropriation of Rs 5 crore funds,” a police officer said. Based on the complaint, the city crime branch police registered a case against the trio and arrested them. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. Coonoor river will be fenced to stop pol.description: UDHAGAMANDALAM: The Coonoor river would soon be fenced and CCTV cameras installed to monitor the area to prevent dumping of waste into it, collector J Innocent Divya said. She warned miscreants of a heavy fine if they indulge in such activities. The collector, who inaugurated a cleaning campaign at Coonoor bus stand on Wednesday, said encroachments of pavements and roads would be viewed very seriously and offenders would be punished. Every shopkeeper should place a bin at the entrance of the shop, she added. Later in the day, the collector presided over Jamabandhi meeting at Coonoor taluk office and received grievances from the public. She received as many as 230 petitions seeking bus service, old age pension, drinking water facility and road facilities. She ordered the concerned officials to take immediate action on the petitions. She also distributed benefits of government welfare schemes to be selected people. Govindarajan, a resident of Coonoor, said, “People who comes to Coonoor steps first into Coonoor bus stand. But it is always untidy. The Coonoor river is exposed to litters as it is located close to the bus stand.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Old answer scripts of AU spill on road.description: Coimbatore: Old answer scripts from the Anna University Regional Campus at Navavoor on Maruthamalai Main Road, which were being carried in a truck to be pulped, spilled on the road at Vadavalli on Monday morning. M Saravanakumar, dean of the campus, said the answer scripts were more than a year old and were being taken to the Tamil Nadu Newsprint and Papers Limited (TNPL) in Karur to be pulped. “As per the government norms, nullified answer scripts that are more than a year old should be taken to TNPL for pulping,” he said. However, the papers spilled on the road at Vadavalli. Another truck was brought to the spot and a portion of the papers from the first truck were transferred to the other one and then taken away. Sources said the papers were not loaded properly on the truck, which might have caused the mishap. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

1 in 6 above age of 40 suffer from overa.description: Coimbatore: ‘I laughed so hard I wet my pants’ is not an expression anymore but a harsh reality, especially for women, say urologists.Urologists in the city estimate that one in six people over the age of 40 suffer from an “overactive bladder” and the incidence increases with age. In this year’s ‘World Continence Week’, which is observed from June 17 to June 23, the theme is ‘incontinence is no laughing matter’. An overactive bladder (OAB), once considered a medical condition affecting the elderly population, is now being seen among younger men and women. “Overactive bladder is a problem where the bladder-storage functions become impaired, resulting in a sudden urge to urinate. In some cases, the urge may be so strong that it can result in leaks before you can reach the bathroom,” urologist at city-based Vedanayagam Hospital Dr Ganesh Gopalakrishnan said. “If you’re using the bathroom more than about eight times in 24-hour and if the urge keeps increasing, this could be a sign that there is something wrong,” he said. Some patients, with OAB, experience leakages when they laugh, sneeze or even jump because it puts pressure on the bladder. “Most people who suffer from urinary incontinence live with it because they believe there is nothing they can do about it,” urologist at GKNM Hospital Dr K S Vengetesh said. “However, people hesitate to discuss it with doctors due to embarrassment. It often leads to low self-esteem and social isolation,” a doctor said. However, another urologist said patients need to be aware that an overactive bladder is a common medical condition and can be treated or managed well. “With OAB, the bladder works overtime, contracting more often than it should and at inappropriate times. The bladder muscles seem to give wrong messages to the brain causing the bladder to feel fuller than it is. The bladder contracts too early when the bladder is not very full,” Dr C L Dinakaran of Arun Urology Hospital said. OAB can be managed with lifestyle changes, diet, medication and even surgery. “It is advisable to limit your caffeine intake, refrain from alcohol and spicy food,” Dr Vengetesh said. Kullu road accident.description: MANALI: At least 44 people have died and 29 sustained injured on Thursday when a bus fell into a gorge in Himachal's Kullu district. Kullu superintendent of police (SP) Shalini Agnihotri said several women and kids were among the injured. The vehicle had started its journey from the Banjar bus stand around 4pm and covered barely 2km when it met with an accident. The driver apparently lost control while negotiating a sharp turn at the Bhiyoth Mor, which has a gradient of more than 75 degrees. Eyewitnesses said the bus veered off the road to scrape the mountain face before hurtling down the gorge. Local residents and police personnel faced difficulty locating and extricating the bodies from the mangled mass of metal. Parts of the vehicle were strewn over a wide swathe of the bottom of the gorge. Between 2009 and 2018, Himachal Pradesh recorded 30,993 road accidents in which 11,561 people were killed and 53,909 injured. This year alone, as many as 430 people died in 1,168 road accidents in the state till May 31. Space constraints delay setting up of pa.description: TIRUPUR: Due to non-availability of required space in post offices, the Union ministry of external affairs and department of posts are struggling to establish a post office passport seva kendra (POPSK) in the city. Under the Coimbatore regional passport office, POPSKs were already set up in Salem, Rasipuram, Erode and Coonoor. To further increase the efficiency in issuing passports, the external affairs ministry has planned to establish at least one POPSK in each parliamentary constituency. Two years ago, it proposed to set up 10 new centres, including in Tirupur, across the state. A postal officer on condition of anonymity said, “Such passport centres would be preferred to be set up in head post offices but Tirupur head post office is already congested with other postal services. So, we took steps to establish the centre at Tirupur collectorate post office. Since the collectorate is a state government building, it did not work out for investment from the central government.” “Though we have space in Avinashi post office, the MEA did not give green signal since Avinashi falls under the Nilgiris parliamentary constituency. The postal department has informed MEA that it has a vacant land on College Road in the dollar city and requested it to see whether it could be utilized for constructing a new building for Tirupur north post office-cum-POPSK,” the officer said. “The postal department also has consulted with the Tirupur district administration whether it could get required space for the centre in a new building constructed for integrated district courts complex inside the collectorate campus,” he added. An official from Coimbatore RPO said, “There should be around 400 sqft for POPSK, and we are looking out for the suitable place in Tirupur. We hope that we will find the space quickly and start the centre, which will cater services to the people from entire district.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Rural police rope in CIT to study accide.description: COIMBATORE: Professors and students of Coimbatore Institute of Technology (CIT) will come out with a detailed report about accident spots in rural Coimbatore and measures to be taken to curb fatal accidents on these spots. The Coimbatore rural police have roped in CIT to conduct a study about fatal accidents in its limit. The professors along with students will visit accident spots and traffic bottlenecks in Pollachi, Mettupalayam, Thudiyalur, Annur, Karumathampatti and Sulur areas. District superintendent of police Sujit Kumar said the team will visit various accident spots in the district and will interact with the motorists and shopkeepers in the localities. A team, led by dean of student affairs Dr S Shanmugam, will visit Karumathampatti on June 19 as part of the study. The team will be accompanied by deputy superintendent of police, Karumathampatti sub-division, inspector of police and sub-inspectors of police from Karumathampatti police. Assistant professor of department of civil engineering J Cyril Santhosh will also be part of the team. “The professors and their teams will be taken to accident spots by police officers. The professors will study the reasons for accidents and will interact with the motorists. They will also suggest short-term and long-term solutions to control fatal accidents. Likewise, the professors and their teams will visit the entire districts to identify accident spots. We expect that they would submit their report within a month,” Sujit Kumar said. He said the report will also be shared with the national highways, state highways and local body. “We can reduce the fatal accidents by join efforts with other departments. If the report suggests installing a street lamp to provide lighting facilities, we will send the report to the respective authorities,” Sujit Kumar said. He said the detailed report will help the rural police to control accidents rates in the district. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Rs 280cr investment proposals from distr.description: Coimbatore: Of the total investment proposals of about Rs 4,000crore for which memoranda of understandings (MoUs) were signed at the Global Investors Meet (GIM) held in January, proposals amounting to Rs 283.14crore have been actualised so far, the District Industries Centre (DIC) revealed. The actualised investments amounted to 456 investment proposals, DIC general manager R Kannan said. “The proposals realised so far were from small investors. The investments were in sectors such as engineering workshops, coir units and garment units,” he said. Some of the investors had already started production, Kannan told TOI. “Investors, who already had buildings, had invested in new machines for starting new businesses. These small investments required purchase of machinery such as computer numerical control (CNC) machines, buying which was a simple process.” At the GIM 2019, investors from Coimbatore had signed MoUs for a total of 2,411 investment proposals amounting to Rs 4,000crore. They have two years to actualise the proposals. “For this, officials will contact the investors and follow up the status of their projects,” Kannan said. “Also, to ease the process of actualising investment proposals, the officials would hold a meeting with bank officials in the presence of district administration officials. They would identify pending bank loans in connection with GIM proposals and would intervene to speed-up the process.” A major chunk of GIM investment proposals from Coimbatore comprises setting up of industry clusters. Officials said one of the biggest project was the setting up of a textile cluster for Rs 1,000crore. Other major investments include proposals for industrial estates by organisations such as the Coimbatore Sidco Industrial Estate Manufacturers Welfare Association (Cosiema) and the Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises’ (TACT). Farmers seek permission to graze their c.description: COIMBATORE: A group of cattle farmers from villages in and around Thondamuthur on Monday approached the district collector seeking permission to graze their cows in forest land. They said the population of native cattle breeds, especially the Malai Kongu Maadu, had dropped drastically after farmers were banned from grazing their cattle in reserve forest zones. They also demanded that the price at which Aavin buys A2 milk from farmers should be tripled, to encourage more farmers to breed and maintain native cow breeds. Farmers led by the Kongu Patteeshwaran Ghoshala have requested the collector to make the forest department again issue “patti passes” to cattle farmers. “This is a pass that the forest department was issuing to allow us to graze our cattle in forest areas and lands. Around the year 2000-’01, there were nearly 1.5 lakh to 2 lakh Malai Kongu Maadu cows across villages in and around Thondamuthur, including Madhampatti, Karadimadai and Viraliyur,” T Shanmugam, a member of the Ghoshala, said. “However, in 2002, when the forest department withdrew our patti passes and banned ours and our cattle’s entry in forest areas, many farmers panicked and sold thousands of their native cows to slaughter houses. We have a few thousand cows of the native breed left,” he said. The farmers said the government should incentivize rearing of native breeds of cattle. “While one way is to allow us to graze in forest areas, the other one is to make Aavin buy A2 milk from us farmers for at least Rs 50 to Rs 60 per litre. They currently buy it for Rs 20 per litre, which is the cost for A1 milk. They have only one category called milk,” Shanmugam said. “They should also ban construction on hill area conservation lands and foothills of mountains, because it eventually takes away greenery and open lands which can be used for grazing,” he added. The cattle farmers said the ban on cattle has affected their environment in multiple ways. “Whenever our cattle used to graze in the forest fringes, wild animals never came out of the forest. We have never seen wild elephants, bears and leopards. Now, they have begun coming inside our villages. The grazing cow’s urine and dung was so beneficial to the soil that the forests were thicker, and they used to eat grass so well that fresh grass kept growing. Now we have less greenery and temperature is higher. We have also had to start using chemical pesticides, because we don’t have enough cow urine to make biopesticides,” the petition said. Narendra Modi.description: RANCHI: Appealing to people to take yoga to all sections of society, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said yoga is above everything, as he performed various asanas with around 40,000 enthusiasts at the Prabhat Tara ground here to mark the fifth International Day of Yoga. Modi also urged people to make yoga an integral part of life. International Yoga Day 2019: PM urges country to embrace Yoga"We should make efforts to take yoga from cities to villages and tribal areas. Yoga is above religion, caste, colour, gender and region, it is above everything," he told the gathering. Yoga is ancient and modern. It is constant and evolving. For centuries, the essence of Yoga has remained the same… https://t.co/isvMOUTrn8— PMO India (@PMOIndia) 1561080804000The main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Best pictures from International Yoga Day 2019"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Follow live updates: International Yoga DayThe main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Amit Shah credits PM for taking yoga to the world"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Expressing concern that young people are becoming vulnerable to heart ailments, Modi said, "Yoga can play a huge role in tackling the issue and hence, this year's theme is 'Yoga for Heart'." "It is painful to read about alcoholism, substance abuse, diabetes and other things, adding yoga offers a solution to these problems," he added. He stressed that for yoga to become popular, infrastructure for it must be strengthened and said the government was working towards it. "Peace and harmony are related to yoga. People across the world must practice it," Modi said. The prime minister had arrived in Ranchi on Thursday night. On his way out of the venue, Modi shook hands with several participants, including school children, who reached out to the prime minister over barricades. The International Day of Yoga is being celebrated annually on June 21 since 2015. Yoga Day.description: The world marks the fifth edition of International Day of Yoga on June 21, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. Organic matter in farmland soil dipped,.description: COIMBATORE: The amount of organic matter in farmland soil has drastically come down in the state due to indiscriminate use of chemical pesticides and fertilisers, experts, who attended the state-level soil health card workshop organised by the state department of agriculture held at the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) here revealed on Monday. Due to indiscriminate use of chemical fertilisers and pesticides, microbes and earthworms were destroyed and the soil has become lifeless, said joint director of agriculture S Banumathi., who spoke at the inaugural function. “Crops cultivated in such soil don’t have good growth and fall prey to insects and diseases. Due to soil pollution and climate change, the organic nutrients of soil in the state, which was 1.26% in 1980, had come down to 0.68% in 2013-2014,” she said. “To compensate this, the health of the soil has to be analysed frequently and organic fertilisers have to be used.” During the Green Revolution, chemical fertilisers were used to increase production to cater to a growing population and health of the soil came down due to that, the experts said. “In today’s scenario of growing population and shrinking cultivable land area, productivity per unit cultivable area has to be increased,” said Azhagu Nagendran, deputy director of agriculture, Theni. “To address this issue, in 1995, the state had started the soil health card scheme as a pilot project in three districtsDharmapuri, Kanchipuram and Trichy. Under the scheme, soil nutrients in agricultural lands were tested and farmers were given booklets about soil health.” Under the renewed mission on soil health card, a part of the National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture, the state has been testing soil samples and giving soil health cards in two phases from 2016. A total of 30 soil testing laboratories and 16 mobile soil testing laboratories have been functioning across the state for the purpose. A total of 9.61lakh soil samples were tested in the two phases. TNAU vice-chancellor N Kumar said soil health management plays a major role in increasing productivity and reducing farmers’ expense. The workshop, which was attended by as many as 200 officials and 100 farmers from across the state, featured sessions on suitable fertiliser prescriptions, soil organic nutrient management and bio-fertilisers. Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Al Umma founder gets 15 days parole.description: Coimbatore: A police team dropped Coimbatore serial bomb blasts mastermind SA Basha at his house at Bilal Estate in Ukkadam on Thursday morning after the Madras high court granted him parole for 15 days. The 72-year-old man will be taken back to the Coimbatore Central Prison on July 4.Basha was the founding president of banned militant fundamentalist outfit Al Umma and had planned the serial blasts on February 14, 1998. The chargesheet filed by the special investigation team of CB-CID against Basha on May 5, 1999 accused him of conspiring to kill BJP leader LK Advani using a suicide squad and for the post-blast violence. He arranged the procurement of about 650kg gelatin and other explosive substances from Mysuru to make various types of bombs and IEDs in Coimbatore.Subsequently, Basha was sentenced to life imprisonment by the special court for bomb blast cases. He spent more than 21 years in the prison here. His appeal is pending before the Supreme Court.Basha’s daughter Mubeena had approached the HC seeking one month parole for her father claiming that her mother’s health had deteriorated.While he can spend time with his family, Basha is barred from venturing out of his house or meeting members of political outfits, police sources said.The city police have been deployed 20 police personnel at the house round-the-clock.Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Public libraries get new books.description: COIMBATORE: After a gap of four years, libraries in the district would soon get new books through library orders by the state government. Half of the books have already arrived at the district central library on Cowley Brown Road here, where library personnel would sort the books and dispatch them to branch and village libraries in the district. “So far around 50% of the books for the district have been received. We expect the others to arrive soon,” said librarian P Rajendran. He said, on average, 267 libraries in the district, which include branch libraries, village libraries and part-time libraries, would receive 2,000 books each, while the district central library would receive around 5,000 books. The process of sorting out the books, numbering them and dispatching to libraries would take around six months, he added. The state directorate of public libraries had not called for library orders from publishers for the past four years citing fund crunch. Recently, they had called for library orders of books published in 2016-17, said officials at the library. Books from 142 English publishers and 517 Tamil publishers had been called for and the publishers have been sending the books to district central libraries across the state. Earlier publishers had been asked to send specimen copies to the directorate. Selected books would be delivered to district central libraries in the state by publishers themselves, said officials. Meanwhile, the annual batch of new books — 5,299 copies of English books and 25,300 copies of Tamil books — from the Raja Rammohan Roy Library Foundation (RRRLF), under the Union ministry of culture, has already arrived at the central library, Rajendran said. “We would start dispatching the books to 31 libraries in a week,” he said. IS module: NIA seizes 2 hard disks from.description: COIMBATORE: National Investigation Agency (NIA) sleuths seized two hard disks that had content propagating Islamic State (IS) ideology during a search at the house of one M Shinod, 35, at BK Pudur near Kuniyamuthur here on Thursday. Shinod was a friend of Mohammed H Azarudeen, 32, who was arrested by the NIA, Kochi, along with Y Shiek Hidhayathullah, 38, last week for spreading IS ideology among youth. Azarudeen told officials that he had handed over two hard disks to Shinod. Based on this, the NIA team from Kochi brought Azarudeen to the house of Shinod around 1pm, interrogated Shinod and seized the hard disks. The search lasted over 30 minutes. Officials from the special intelligence cell (SIC) of the Coimbatore city police and the special intelligence unit (SIU) of the state police also came to the spot and questioned Shinod, who was a computer service man. When reporters contacted Shinod, he refused to speak. According to sources, Azarudeen and Sheik Hidhayathullah were taken into custody for five days by the NIA on an order by the special court for NIA cases in Kochi. As the custody will get over on Friday, the accused will be produced before the special court and lodged in prison in Kochi. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Chennai resident held for theft.description: COIMBATORE: The rural police on Monday arrested a 40-year-old man from Chennai for stealing 34 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 3.10lakh, which were kept in a parked scooter at Lakshmi Bhavan Complex at Periyanaickenpalayam a week ago. Police recovered 31 sovereigns of gold ornaments from him. The arrested person was identified as G Venkatesh of Manali in Chennai, an autorickshaw driver. B Subash Chandra Bose of Gudalur Goundampalayam near Periyanaickenpalayam, who runs a photo studio in Lakshmi Bhavan Complex, had withdrawn the valuables from the Indian Overseas Bank on June 7. He kept them in the box under the scooter seat and returned to the studio. He returned to the parked vehicle after 15 minutes to find the valuables missing. Based on his complaint, Periyanaickenpalayam police registered a case. Preliminary inquiry revealed that Venkatesh, who was waiting in front of the bank, had noticed Bose carrying the valuables. He followed him to the studio and stole them from the scooter. Venkatesh told police that he spent the money and sold three sovereigns of gold ornaments.
